NewsLine.NewsLineText: IVORYCOAST-ANARCHY:Ivory Coast turmoil sets region on precipice

body.p: By Matthew Tostevin

ABIDJAN, Sept 23 (Reuters) - "Ivory Coast faces a possibility worse than a coup: an anarchic implosion of criminal violence... Or it may become an African Yugoslavia, but one without mini-states to replace the whole."

So wrote Robert D. Kaplan in 1994, warning of "The Coming Anarchy" in West Africa and other poverty-blighted corners of the world in an influential article attacked by critics at the time as overly gloomy and simplistic.
But Kaplan's fears caught up with Ivory Coast last week.

Ivory Coast's eruption of violence between dissident troops and President Laurent Gbagbo's loyalists has pushed the region closer to an edge beyond which the world could find it near impossible to rescue.

"The time to intervene is now. If you leave it any longer then it could be too late. Nobody can win this kind of war," said one Liberian exile who fled a dozen years of repression and conflict in his own country for refuge in Abidjan.

So far the only intervention is by troops from former colonial power France and strictly with the aim of protecting -- and if need be pulling out -- foreigners rather than saving another crumbling African state from itself.

The decline of West Africa's former jewel has been steady, through personal political power games, xenophobia, growing ethnic tension, a 1999 coup and clashes around 2000 elections in which hundreds died.
HUGE THREAT TO REGION
The regional consequences of it slipping deeper could be much more serious than the wars that ripped apart nearby Liberia and Sierra Leone with the loss of some 250,000 lives.

"If it does escalate further, it is going to be extremely bad news because of Ivory Coast's port, because of its cocoa," said Rachel Codd of London-based consultancy Control Risks Group. "I am hoping things will calm down for negotiation."

Ivory Coast is not only the world's top cocoa grower, it is Africa's third biggest economy, the engine of the French-backed West African CFA franc currency zone and a vital port for landlocked countries to the north.
The country's more than 16 million people could create a refugee crisis spreading contagion to its neighbours and hugely inflating the number seeking to escape to the West.

Its past security made it a regional base for multinational firms, U.N. bodies and the huge offices of the African Development Bank, while its relative prosperity tugged in millions of immigrants supporting families abroad.
The presence of the immigrants binds Ivory Coast more closely to its neighbours and them more tightly to it, making serious repercussions of any prolonged crisis inevitable.
Fears the conflict will spread have already been raised by Ivory Coast's suggestion foreign hands are behind the turmoil and by attacks by loyalist security forces on immigrant workers.

As in many other African crises, "security forces" appears to have become a cynical misnomer for the biggest purveyors of instability -- one group of soldiers creating the problem and another inflaming it with a heavy-handed response.
HARD TO STAMP OUT
The experience of Ivory Coast's neighbours is that once that kind of turmoil starts it is very hard to stamp out.

The Liberian army's murderous reaction when a small group of dissidents attacked a border post in late 1989 helped turn it into a seven-year war. Liberia's respite from bloodshed lasted only three years before another war began.
Sierra Leone thought in the early 1990s it had wiped out a brutal rebel movement, but the fighters had simply melted into the bush and struck again when they saw a chance.

Behind both wars were armies of disaffected youths, without jobs, without hope, bitter at tribal favouritism and exclusion by corrupt elites. Once they join up, their own atrocities make them outcasts with nothing to lose by carrying on.

Those were exactly the kind of youths being pressed into service and handed guns by Ivory Coast's rebels in the cities of Bouake and Korhogo after what the dissident troops said was simply a protest about being kicked out of the army.

When the world eventually stepped in to end Sierra Leone's cycle of murder, rape and amputation, it took the biggest United Nations peacekeeping force and $700 million a year to bring peace to a country the size of Scotland.
The argument of those who favour intervention is that failed African states become nests of crime and terrorism.
But Ivory Coast has more than three times as many people as Sierra Leone and is more than four and a half times as big.
"This country is central to the region and if it goes the consequences will be awful," said one African diplomat.
"It is already becoming a regional crisis with the attacks on foreigners and if it goes that far, then I am not sure how it would be possible for anyone to rescue a whole region."
